title: 114_hr2154
content: The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2015" may be cited as the short title. This Act includes provisions for distracted driving grants. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2015" includes amendments to Section 405(e) of title 23, United States Code, regarding penalties for offenses related to distracted driving. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2015" amends Section 405(e) of title 23, United States Code by updating penalties for distracted driving offenses. This includes prohibiting handheld cell phone use while driving and allowing the use of hands-free devices for drivers over 18 years old. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2015" updates penalties for distracted driving offenses, prohibiting handheld cell phone use while driving for individuals over 18 years old. The law makes violations a primary offense, establishes minimum penalties for first violations, and increases penalties for repeat violations. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2015" updates penalties for distracted driving offenses, including fines, points on a driver's record, or similar state actions as penalties. The amendments will take effect on October 1 of the first fiscal year after the enactment of the Act. The amendments will take effect on October 1 of the first fiscal year after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. RESEARCH PROGRAM. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a research program within 180 days to study distracted driving by motor vehicle drivers. The program will focus on driver behavior, vehicle technology, and portable electronic devices commonly used in vehicles. Research contracts may be granted to nongovernmental entities, with limitations on those producing or selling electronic equipment for vehicles. The Secretary of Transportation will submit a report to Congress on the results of a research program studying distracted driving by motor vehicle drivers, focusing on electronic equipment in vehicles and portable devices. The Federal Communications Commission will provide a report to Congress on data, technology, and authority related to reducing distracted driving involving personal wireless devices.
